comment:
Appearance: light caramel in color 

Nose: Sweet Apple and Oak dominate 

Palate: very gentle at first.  Heat begins to seep him slowly. Very simple flavor profile. Oak dominates, but I’m sure the more experienced enthusiast could pick out some of the more gentle flavors. Mouthfeel is a little on the thin side.  

Finish: finishes strong.  Lingers long after the sip.  Heat is just about right - would not have minded a little more kick in the end.   

Good bourbon for the price point. Due to mouthfeel being a little thin, I think It would be enjoyable in a chilled glass, but even a big cube may water it down a little much.
This is a classic bourbon. Nothing super special buts it’s a good solid sipper at a great price
Smooth over ice no after bite, smooth finish

Nose: Maple, slight vanilla.

Palatte: Apricot, honey, maple.

Finish: smooth. Sweet aftertaste, like thin maple syrup and honey
Sweet, vanilla, smooth, a little cinnamon on the finish, spice. Lingering clove.
Sweet pipe tobacco and oak neat. Caramel and vanilla when water is added.

Yet another store pick from Elijah Craig, mostly going to focus on the difference between this pick and the standard offering. (Standard disclaimer that this review is primarily for my own records and most likely completely useless to those outside the Phoenix, AZ area)

Total Wine and More pick Barrel 5589802 Rickhouse T, Floor 6, 9 yr age

Nose on this one is killer; Lemonhead’s candy, and a big spice bouquet (allspice, ginger, and clove) that makes you want to dive right in. Some sweetness underneath but spices steal the show. 

On the palate this one is a like hot caramel bomb. Initial taste of Rollo’s candy followed by barrel spices and char, and ending with an oaky finish. Flavors richer, more integrated, and flow more smoothly from one flavor to next over the standard fare which I feel is too astringent on the finish.

One of the better EC picks I have had. Been slurping this down like water since I bought it. A rebuy at the standard TW pricing of $32.
Nose of vanilla and smoke/char, hotter than most 94 proof, but not as hot as cask strength. Good spice level, and not too sweet.
Definitely get leather in the nose, also some sweet caramel.  Not as hot as the notes say; maybe compared to the 12 year. Very good for $29.

Nose: cherry, vanilla, oak, and lots of root beer

Palate: cinnamon and a little star anise

Finish: heat from the spice, a bit oily and a little drying on the tongue
Cherry & chocolate on the nose. Cream and apple flavors. Short floral finish.
Apple, honey, and slight vanilla give way to a hot finish.  Pretty tasty overall and great price point.

Like an old friend that you don’t really like that much but keep hanging out with. Sometimes he’s kinda fun and cracks an ok joke, but mostly you are thinking “how did I get stuck with him again?” 
That said, you keep hanging out with him and can’t quite commit to dropping him entirely; and when you mention this to your other buddies, they act like you are overreacting.
I get vanilla and some butterscotch on the nose. Butterscotch stays on the palate initially but fades quick to spice that lasts.

Nose: sweet, flowery, cherry, vanilla
Taste: Carmel, spicy, cinnamon.
Finish: long very pleasant.

Store pick so slight difference to the regular shelfer. Nose is very light with no stand out notes. Initial taste is a bit spicey as if it has a heavy rye mash. After an initial pepper burn it mellows nicely to reveal hints of vanilla and mild brown sugar. Closes with a medium burn and light cinnamon close. Decent sip at the price point and defintely preferred to the Buffalo Trace and Larceny entry level pours.

Nose sweet pecan
Neat - hot sweet cherry 
Ice and water- sweet leather
Compared to Bulleit and Benchmark and fell between the two, still prefer Benchmark.  Good bourbon. Slight brown sugar. Medium feel, wintergreen burn. Medium finish. Solid for its price.
This is a keeper. Not complex, easy drinking. All honey and oak. Hard to score higher if you know what it replaced (a 12 year ace).

My benchmark bourbon

Mash bill: 78% Corn, 10% Rye, 12% barley

Nose: caramel, sweet corn, cough medicine persists (candied cherry, do not like it too much), barely detectable nut, pepper, finish with oak

Palate: still practicing taste, too much alcohol for now, first time bitter (stay too long in the back of tongue), diluting with water helps; second time better. After sampling a cheap $20 blended cowboy whiskey, I appreciate EC’s Co complexity much more

Finish: long, 1-2 mins, coating mouth

Balance: complex, layers of flavor, wood residual fragrance at the bottom of glass
An excellent bourbon for the price. Not mind blowing as smooth or flavor but for the price a very dependable bottle. Great for cocktails
An update to my initial taste using a different rating system. Color and nose are EC’s strengths; but the astringent biting brightness that lingers is a real turn off for me.

BACKGROUND: Elijah Craig bourbon is named for a Baptist minister from Virginia who moved to Kentucky and opened a distillery in 1789.  

Legend claims, though absolutely no proof exists, that Craig accidentally invented the process of aging whiskey in charred barrels after his barn caught fire.  Despite the fact that the fire, according to lore, charred barrels that were stored inside the barn, Craig decided to use them to ship his whiskey.  Customers who received the barrels were supposedly delighted with the effect that barrel char had upon its contents, and a new method of aging was born…or not.

Before his death in 1809, Craig’s distillery and farm would encompass roughly 4,000 acres, which were tended by several of his slaves, and he also operated a retail store in Frankfort, Kentucky to sell his bourbon product.

One of Craig’s contemporaries wrote at the time, “His preaching was of the most solemn style; his appearance as of a man who had just come from the dead; of a delicate habit, a thin visage, large eyes and mouth; the sweet melody of his voice, both in preaching and singing, bore all down before it.”

Though one would assume that a bourbon named after an 18th Century distiller would have a long and storied history, the first bottle of Elijah Craig was produced by Heaven Hill distillery only in 1986, and it used the same 78% corn, 10% rye, and 12% malted barley age statement as today.

Once carrying a 12-year age statement, it has since been dropped, and the bourbon is made from a blend of younger whiskies. A single barrel Elijah Craig with an 18-year age statement is still available, however.

The 94-proof, NAS bottle I sampled is a pick by the Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control agency.

NOSE: The nose is reminiscent of a gentlemen’s club - not the strip club kind but the formal and elite kind with monocle-wearing dudes sporting smoking jackets - and offers a great combination of pipe tobacco, leather, and maple syrup..

PALATE: Despite the fact that it has no age statement, Elijah Craig has the same significant amount of oak as most well-aged bourbons.  Caramel and brown sugar are present, and a strong hint of cherries develops on the back of the palate.

FINISH: Oak and barrel char dominate the medium-to-long finish, but it is not at all drying.  A pleasant heat rises but stops and simmers at just the right level.

FINAL ASSESSMENT:  The ABC Select Spirits Elijah Craig barrel pick is a good, but not great, bourbon.  Though not complex, it is perfectly pleasant and does its job.  For the price of $24.99, it’s a satisfying daily drinker.
Good to great. Smoother than the Makers 46. Caramel smell.

Classic bourbon, indeed.

Aroma: caramels and vanilla abound.

Taste: aromas are amplified and supported by warm baking spices.  It coats the mouth and the complexity builds by sip 3.

Finish: the finish is just as flavorful as the taste, long, complex, and warm.
Sweet and warm, thick viscosity, nice spice on the finish.
Vanilla and butterscotch with a little bit of spices on the tail end. Very smooth.
Really not a bad bourbon, but far too sweet for my tastes
Smooth up front, a bit harsh on the finish. Notes of vanilla and cherry

Working on my rating methodology and determining how my average rating lands. 
That said, ECSB has grown on me some; I was not impressed at first pour but with time, I’ve made peace with this bottle. 

That sweet, corny shine hits the nose with that cherry almost grenadine undertone. The palate is a boxing match between oak and meager heat being refereed by a Luden’s cough drop.
Barrel spice, vanilla bean ice cream, spices, smoky
Oaky nasal with hints of floral and egg nog. Goes down smooth with a sweet caramel maple taste in the back of the throat.

This is an ideal sipping whiskey. The nose has a bit of oakiness and sweet vanilla. For the taste, you definitely get a bit of nutty vanilla and a good amount of heat, as the rye kicks through. Low price point, solid quality.

The nose is great.  The heat is real.  
Drinking neat
Smooth pour neat. No appreciable headache.
Packs a lot of flavor. Very stiff drink, but in the best way.
I like the price compared to the taste ratio.

COLOR/ Dark Caramel Butterscotch
AROMA/ Butterscotch, Wood, Sweetness, Caramel, Slight Hint of Honey, Some Nouget, Some Alcohol, Sweet Corn
FIRST SIP/ Smoothness on the Tongue, Sweetness, Mash, Slight Corn, 
TASTE/ Rich and Complex, Sweetness, Some Butter, Smoothness, Honey, Nutty, Caramels, Slight Woodiness
FINISH/ Rich, Smooth, Sweetness, Slight Warming Alcohol, Lingering Buttery Taste 
MT GLASS/ Wood, Sweetness
94 proof

This my friends is a delightful beverage. This small batch is so smooth, rich and full of complex flavors, smells and tastes. This is a beverage that should be enjoyed neat. This is an overall delightful bottle that deserves your attention when you can find it. Enjoy it with a friend or family savoring the love, the care, the craftsmansship and the passion that is put into this enjoyable straight bourbon whiskey. While drinking this with friends and family enjoy their company with care, passion and love. 

Be Kind, Be Generous, Be Real, Be Responsible!!!
CH33RS
Smooth with no burn, great with Coke.
Mild flavor compared to other bourbon whiskey. It seems like scotch whiskey
Vanilla, little alcohol mouthfeel, very mellow
Vanilla, oak, sweet in the middle & finish. Slightly higher heat in the finish. Might try with an ice cube next time. Very good bourbon for the price.

Lebanon Wine and Spirits Pick 
Nose was Caramel and butterscotch.
Mouth was full of bold flavor. Not extremely thick... a great consistency. 
Finish on this 94 proof was longer than some rare hard to find bourbons. Lingers forever
My go to!  High fives Heaven Hill :-)
The scent isn’t as strong as one would think, the taste is spot on for a small batch. Burn is subtle and doesn’t overpower.

A pretty mellow bourbon with a great smell and wonderful finish. I’m not particularly impressed with the flavor and find the mouth somewhat dry. But, on the other hand, the front is sweet with a bold cinnamon spice follow. I suspect more complexity underneath.
Smells good.  Tastes lovely with a strong burn at first, but doesn't linger.

Nose - apple, cherry, caramel, buttery cinnamon, brown sugar, vanilla, oak, moderate ethanol burn. 

Taste - cherry, cinnamon, brown sugar, caramel, vanilla, barrel notes, moderate ethanol burn, finishing reasonably long with bittersweet cherry and burnt sugar flavors.

One of my favorite small batch bourbons, even with the change from 12 yr labeling to NAS.  Still one of the best noses in bourbon for me.  Not the stale maple syrup (not a bad thing) anymore, but rich butterscotch caramel.  The higher corn percentage in the mashbill gives it a sweetness that is given a rich depth by getting to know the oak barrel for awhile.  The color, nose, taste, and finish tells you that there's still some 12 year juice in here.  Sip it neat and enjoy a Kentucky hug.
Smooth bourbon, one of my new favs.
Really great bottle for the price, has a little more heat and proof than other bottles in the price range. If you like this , try to get some Barrel Proof =)
Fantastic nose, taste and finish. Nothing fancy, little variation from classic bourbon, but just wonderfully solid.

This is the bourbon that started me down this damn rabbit hole, so it has a special place on my shelf to be transparent.  But, its also, it deserves that spot. The nose has wonderful layers of crisp apple, vanilla, and cinnamon. Not apple pie, to fresh and 'crispy' for that.  Then the palate delivers a nice oily mouth feel, with great fruitiness and sweetness on the front. Then the spice and char hit, with a nice but not too hot cinnamon and oak to finish it. I wouldn't call this smooth, but it is not the alcohol that makes the burn, it is the rye and heavy char making a nice robust flavor. What a bourbon should be, and this is an incredible price point.  Not many better offerings in the $20-$30 range.
Strong, warm, almost oily with a spiced tone. Good but nothing new

Nose: Sweet
Palate: Honey, Butterscotch
Finish: Not too lingering, honey
I just can't get into this one for some reason. Nose on mine is alcohol and cinnamon with some oak. Taste follows suit. Burns a bit. Not my favorite value bourbon

Now, this is what an almost perfect amount of heat in a bourbon feels (and tastes) like. It should light up the back of the teeth without burning the throat; it should create just an edge of novocaine in the cheeks (just the cheeks, not the tongue or the roof of the mouth) without actually numbing. Taste? Oily, a little plum, a little honey, a little raisin, a bit of tobacco, a bit more rum. A very fine experience, for the shelf just below the top.
Sweet and smooth. Vanilla. Hint of caramel? Need to get a bottle of this.
Solid, but nothing that I feel like I need to have again
Notes of honey and a little floral bouquet. Taste like a spice cookie, cinnamon, sugar, and vanilla. Low to medium heat.

Lighter, smooth tastes of apples, butterscotch, and a bit of vanilla and raisin bran flakes with a puff of smoke to finish. Short finish that tapers all the way through these flavors but has a bit of a spice to cap things off.
Rich, and deep. The butterscotch, vanilla and oak come out in a symphonic crescendo on the palate, with a little spice. The finish is long and buttery
Vanilla on the nose. Caramel and nutmeg flavor with hot spice burn at the end
Toasted sugar and warm vanilla on the nose, caramel and mint on the palate, pencil shavings on the finish.
Still a really flavorful bourbon at a great price.

Nose
Cherry, caramel, vanilla, orange 

Palate
Barrel spice
Apples
Vanilla
Honey
A solid bourbon. Good and smooth but still a bourbon hug and flavor

My idea of what a “Classic Bourbon” should be. Rich notes of brown sugar and molasses, with a hint of cherry/vanilla. Definitely get a lot of the oak taste in the finish, but not as present on the nose. This will be a staple in my bar cart for years to come.

Rich nose, robust leather, oak, & vanilla, hints of smoke, starts soft, gradual building burn, rich notes of oak, vanilla, hints of apple & smooth velvety, gentle smooth oak/vanilla finish.
Tasted neat in a rocks glass.
Smooth and spicy, not too sweet , a great down the middle bourbon with a little bite
Smooth, not too sweet and a slight bite.  A great down the middle bourbon
Good flavor. Falls into the flavor characteristics I enjoy.
Carmel and vanilla notes with a light oak char.  It has bit of lingering oak flavor.  Nice when mellowed with a few cubes!
Nice option to be quarantined with!  Crisp flavor with a little heat to keep it interesting. Nice, easy finish.
Tastes like creme brûlée and Werther’s. Not nearly as formidable as the barrel proof but definitely worth it for half the $$.
A pie with lots of spice, cinnamon, and crust... then a little bit of tart apple. Cinnamon spice holds on

Nose: vanilla, honey. Bits of cloves and black pepper and apples. A little bit of smoke, but also some acetone and rubbing alcohol. 

Taste: mostly oak and vanilla. Some sweetness, moreso if you let it open up for 10 minutes. Not as comlex as I expected based on reviews. 

Finish: oak and heat. Could definitely use some more time in the barrel.
I remember trying the barrel proof and while it was good it wasn't life changing. This is very much the same. Not disappointing but I wouldn't seek it out either.
I like it. It's like a higher end Heaven Hill White Label with a higher price.

Light brown sugar. Hints of vanilla, cinnamon, clove and charred oak. Well balanced with floral and herbal notes with citrus undertones. This is a great traditional bourbon. One of the best for the price. Must have in your bar.

Nose - caramel and mint jump out at you, with some sour cherry, barrel spice and baking spices
Taste - vanilla, caramel, and oak spice, some red apple, and vague herbal notes that could be grass or mint
Finish - starts out sweet then transitions to spice on the middle of your tongue, it lingers for quite awhile, a good amount of heat but it’s comforting
Smooth. Just smooth🥃. Doesn’t taste strong. Sweet to the nose and very sweet tasting!

I am really loving Elijah Craig Small Batch. The nose is molasses, and that wonderful charred oak. I am getting a touch of Elmer's glue from a squeeze bottle. Mild ash from a vanilla tobacco. With a droplet I get definite maple.

The oaky char hits the sides of the tongue, along with a mild burn. There is a smoldering and burnt out fireworks taste that adds such a lovely, ashy quality. The heat acts as a welcome counterpoint to the flavor, and not a barrier.

The spicy wood and citrus rind/peel adds a spiky little second wave; orange rind absolutely hangs out in the finish. The body is full and chewy. It's gives you a little smoke early on, before rewarding you with a spicy finish.
A good standard bourbon. All the hallmarks: vanilla, corn, and caramel. Middle of the road but good for the price.
Sweet and smooth upfront. Mildly spicey finish. Impressive for $25

4/18/20 immediate sweet aroma. Along With rocky patel freedom, 6$ cigar. Medium body smoke. First dram taste okay. Some sweetness. Round two: not getting sweet finish but maybe some caramel up front . Not getting it today.

Give it a 88/100.
Aroma:  vanilla cherry coke with a little buttered popcorn.
Taste:  wood forward.  Maple brown sugar, a little spice on the tip of the tongue.
Visual:  great caramel coloring
Value:  $ awesome.  Great everyday sipper

This is just good bourbon. Smell is great with small notes of leather and maybe tobacco with a slight ethanol. Taste to me is honey, vanilla, and oak at the beginning then settles into a robust smooth oak, leather and very small hint of pepper spice. This is a great bourbon for a beginner or an enthusiast. Very easily drinkable neat and on the rocks. Really enjoying this one as a go to bourbon that is easily available under 30$. Found ranging from 24 - 30$ in my area.
A good value bourbon, spicy and oaky as hell.  Will buy again.
Sharp at first but quickly smooth and easy to drink.

SIP #1: Nose of apple cider vinegar or that blast of fumes that hits you when you walk into a busy nail salon. Initial spicy and hot bite hides the leather and vanilla, fades into that taste like you get when you’re almost ready to swallow a bite of red apple but all that’s left in your mouth to chew is the bitter red peel. For me, this is like a knock off eagle rare. It will love you long time, but don’t post any pictures as you won’t be proud tomorrow.
SIP #2: "Nose of bitter red apple peel and fresh out of the box tennis shoes, flash of sugar cube sweetness on the lips, red popsicle on the tip of your tongue, with a hot but thin finish. Shines like a cubic zirconia on a MILF in a red dress."

I agree with the consistent finding of a great value bourbon. Nice warmth. I can smell a burnt brown sugar sweetness that comes through early in the flavor. Lingering honey flavor. I really like the balance.

Very lite body, with a warm up front feel on the pallet, however fades fast and doesn't leave much behind. Hints of vanilla,  traces of caramel, but nothing that stood out to strong, not a bad whiskey to get someone new to it, to try

Nose with butterscotch & vanilla as well as some ethanol that permeate from my glencairn glass.  The palate is nice with oak and leather flavors that mingle with the classic caramel.   More heat than one would expect in a 94 proof whiskey, but smooth enough for a beginner.  Medium finish with a warmth that’s felt all the way down.  Although it scores a bit lower as it can’t be confused with WLW or even a Booker’s release, this is a really good pour for the price point.

Light, fruity, heavier baking spices, nose similar to 1792 BiB, taste similar to 4R. Not in same league as ECBP.

I use the rating scale below. Distiller uses a scale of 5 and I use a scale of 10, but I’m sure you’re not too drunk to do the math! 

1. Disgusting - So bad I poured it out.
2. Poor - I wouldn't consume by choice.
3. Bad - Multiple flaws.
4. Below average - Not bad, but many things I'd rather have.
5. Good - Just average.
6. Very Good - Better than average.
7. Great - Well above average.
8. Excellent - In a league of its own.
9. Incredible - An all-time favorite.
10. Perfect
Red delicious, honey, caramel, cinnamon, and oak. Nice for the money.
Good decent priced bourbon. Tasted buttery and Carmel
Aroma - Toffee and oak / Taste - Smooth and buttery. Slight hints oak / Finish- mellow spice with light smoke
Sweet with a light peppery finish. A go to under $30 bargain bourbon for myself.
Caramel and butterscotch notes, full mouth, medium-heavy after

Might be my favorite bourbon so far. This bourbon feels very light when sipped and is just sweet enough to complement the light, almost cinnamon/cloves/gingerbread spice that you taste throughout the middle. Towards the end, the burn definitely comes forward more and eases you down from the sweetness very well.
Pleasure in a bottle.  Better than some, not a real head turner.
Classic bourbon notes, but had a bit of an alcohol ding. Mine is a store pick, and just has classic brown sugar, caramel, and apples.

Nose - cinnamon with sugar note. Think apple pie & maybe cinnamon sticky roll bun. Craft store scent candle (pre lit) ethanol is very approachable when sniffing deep.

Palate (Kentucky chew) Lit Light Cherry infused cigar, red hots candy, atomic fireball Candy. Spiced sweetness. 

Finish: finish for me lasted about 2 mins after the sip. Long enough savor and make a impact. You'll want more for sure. I did.  

For $19.99 I feel I definitely got my money's worth. It's solid.

Waited till this went on sale $27 then scooped it up. There seems to be a lot of disappointment compared to the 12 yr version. I never tried the 12 but this is supposedly 8yr which is still good by todays standards. Poured neat, good coating and legs. Nose is fantastic! Dark brown sugar, toasted marshmallows, little bit of baking and rye spice with some dusty oak. Very fresh and fragrant. Mouthfeel is thin but soft. Palate comes in hot with spicy cinnamon and caramel, nutmeg, rye dough and hefty black pepper oak. Its vibrant and aggressive flavor verging on harsh but walks the line. Finish is long oak and char with peppery heated cinnamon. This is spicy bourbon yet balanced with sweetness and oak. IMO it delivers on the profile of Four Roses single barrel without the excessive pepper and wood. .......85/100
Had it among 9 other whiskey’s (including 5 other similarly priced Bourbons) and it was a close 2nd place finish among the Bourbons to Four Roses Yellow Label
Lighter than most, notes of smoked vanilla and cinnamon.
Sweet with a nice burn finish, some fruity notes

Bought this for the purpose of making old fashions. To my surprise, this was a wonderful sipper in its own right. Some intial booze burn to get the juices flowing. Aroma is the usual sweet tobacco and vanilla spice found in others in the same category. Flavor is decently rich with notes red apples, cinnamon, subtle honey, and hints of corn flakes on the finish.
Sharp nose with hints of brown sugar. Sweet and rich vanilla palette, spicy. Long and simple finish
Fades fast....limited finish.   Comparable light smell to Four Roses.

Right from the beginning you can tell this is slightly higher proof than the average bourbon. 

Nose is full of caramels, dark fruits and baking spice, with a noticeable ethanol smell as well.

Palate starts off as alcohol burn, but immediately takes a back seat so that you can enjoy the spice, with just the faintest hint of sweetness. Mid palate is full with lots of legs and finishes with a mild but consistent heat. 

A very good bourbon which can hold up to water or ice but doesn't need it. When drinking it I feel like I should be sitting in front of a fire in an old leather chair at Christmas time.. but every other night will have to do.
Very nice spicy at the start and light burn at the end. Pretty smooth finish and nice price.
I smell spice first then vanilla. The finish lasted quite a while. Went down smooth!
Vanilla, butterscotch, oak, cinnamon, heat, smoke. Good but cinnamon heat isn’t my favorite.

Caramel, vanilla, toffee, and a hint of honey are the most prevalent flavors. As you swirl it in your mouth there is a fruity, floral taste that sneaks in.  As you swallow there is a nice sweetness left in your mouth with a little pepper finally showing its head.  Sweet, smooth, little burn.
Spice up front, vanilla notes and burn is strong and long.  Great value.
Smokey bbq and caramel with a sharp burn at the end kinda sweet through out with a corn syrup taste not a big fan of it straight with coke it’s alright

This is lovely. 

I won’t say I got to taste this “properly”, but we had dinner with my neighbor and she was kind enough to buy this for me because she knows I’m a whiskey drinker. High marks just for that. 

I can’t say too much visa vi tasting notes because the focus of the evening was on conversation rather than nosing and tasting, but I can say this was one of the finest bourbons for casual sipping I e had in ages. I’ve been close to loosing my faith in bourbon the past year, and lately if had a few drams, this included, that have helped restore the faith. All the classic bourbon notes are present and perfectly balanced. Why I haven’t tried this before is beyond me. Well done, Heaven Hill. Well done indeed. 

As an addendum, it was a real treat to just interact with another human being (besides my lovely wife) tonight. It was a bonus that this awesome dram got to play a part in that.
Sharp, lingering oak taste, unpleasant.  Nice nose, lite and rounded.

Brown leather is the color of this bourbon, and thin oily legs cling to the glass.

The nose is complex and dry. There are notes of leather, dusty corn, vanilla, cherry syrup, Chardonnay wine , caramel, and salted peanuts.

The palate has notes of caramel, dark chocolate, red apple skins, molasses, and BBQ char.

The finish has notes of baking spices, has a little burn going down, and has a medium-ish length. Cheers!

Total Wine Store Pick (Gilbert AZ)  8yr, Rickhouse G, Floor 7

(This review mostly for my own notes and probably useless to those outside the AZ area and will focus on the difference between this store pick and the standard)

I actually bought this thinking it was a restock of a recent-ish 9 yr pick, and didn’t realize it was a different pick until I got it home. (Oops) Main difference here is less caramel and more fruit forward; specifically baked apple skin. Surprisingly large oak presence on the back end for the age but not as astringent with it as the regular offering. Not many other differences, possibly due to the relatively low age for a EC pick.

All in all a very small improvement with this pick which makes it a decidedly ho-hum affair but on the other hand, TW didn’t do the standard up charge for it so there’s that.

Nose: maple, wood, brown sugar. Typical bourbon. Did get a little earth note.
Taste: syrup sweetness and cinnamon burn oaky finish.

Heavy vanilla, cherry, oak on nose. Very full and lots of depth

A question mark initially on the taste, which moves on to a strong spice that grows and continues to spike for quite some time, until you’re left with mild vanilla.
Okay, vanilla, brown sugar, apple and standard burb

Nose: maple, oak, honey sweetness and a little earthy.
Taste: syrup sweetness then more cinnamon heat than the nose had led you to believe.
So solid for such a readily available bourbon
It’s a deep bourbon, yet it’s also a very tame, somewhat smoky, bourbon.

On the pour, this whiskey has a nice amber/caramel color to it. When you put the glass to the nose, you get what smells like a gentleman's bourbon. Hints of butterscotch and mustiness are primary, with the alcohol coming in too. On the tongue, this bourbon starts out almost seeming like a rye, being hot and spicy. It cools off in the middle while still displaying its 94 proof strength. The swallow is sweet, full, and bold, with the vanilla, corn, butterscotch, and other fruity notes finishing it off -- with a little extra burn on the way down.

This is really good stuff. As I’m expanding my trying different good, yet affordable bourbons,  Elijah Craig is always at the top. This new variation has an updated label stating aged 9 years.  Will buy again!
Solid go to. Vanilla and tobacco
I would serve this to my friends who I don’t want to be my friends anymore. Overrated. The heat takes away all the joy.

Store pick. A world apart from the barrel proof version, which I find oppressive.

The main flavor here (take a guess) is caramel, with an orangey note mixed in, which gives it some acidic brightness. Medium char, a little cinnamon, and just a bit of a floral/ethanol punch to keep you awake. Mysteriously absent are vanilla and cherry, in an otherwise typical bourbon, but I’m not missing them too much.

This won’t blow your mind, but if you’re just looking for some good everyday bourbon-ass bourbon, this is not a bad choice at all. There are basically no flaws to speak of, which is really nice for a $30 bourbon. You can pay a lot more for a lot less.
LW Barrel Pick: Excellent: smooth, spicy & great start to finish

Aroma: Oaky and sweet. Butterscotch, honey, oak, spices, and green apple.

Taste: Sweet and perfumey. Corn, oak, and tasting some cinnamon too. 

Finish: Smooth, both a leathery and sweet aftertaste, buttery linger, and slight sting from the alcohol.

I'm no stranger to strong alcohol, but I don't find this bourbon to be very pleasant to drink. The price is okay if you just want something on the lower shelves to have, but I feel it's too perfumey and unbalanced to simply drink and not think much about it. Also, for just a regular bourbon, the oak is underwhelming but a liking for stronger oak may just be my preference.
Super smooth and clean. So good!

The nose is a simple and Sweet bourbon typical, but not unpleasant. This is a pretty sweet and easy to drink bourbon even at 47% but still has some good flavors and heat. Some water actually increased the complexity and bite for me but I prefer it at 47%. This is likely my new cabinet bottle to keep around for when I'm in the mood for a bourbon. Easy must buy for the usual price point.
Well balanced and smooth with just the right amount of heat
very sweet on the nose, honey and vanilla with a hint of cherry and tea leaves. Woodsy with a spicy bite due to the high proof on the palate.
Good overall but prefer others in the same price range.
Smooth and spicy butterscotch with a sweet finish
Very vanilla with some rye spice.
had it a while ago - remember I liked it (smoother than Woodford Reserve)
Tastes like a classic bourbon, but a little spicier. Can be a little strong, but I like the way the younger is coated. Tastes like vanilla and spices, a little bit oaky
2nd Small Batch I've had. Very smooth. Similar in taste to 1792.
Rich and spicy (almost rye-like spiciness), finishes a bit hot. Smooth and sweet with the addition of ice. Would stand up well in cocktails

This is a store pick. 

Age: 11 years (Bardstown)
Rickhouse: U
Floor: 6
Barrel: 5256743

Liquor Barn Selection (2020)

Nose: honey, dust, oak, caramel, leather

Taste: rich with heavy nutmeg, hints of butterscotch and a little vanilla 

Finish: decent amount of bite compared to previous bottles of this I’ve had. And a medium finish. 

Being this bourbon is one year younger than what used to be the standard Elijah Craig 12-year, I had high hopes for this one. It’s a little flat in my opinion. The nose is very nice but it doesn’t deliver by the finish. Will have to come back and revisit this after a few weeks of the bottle being opened. 

However, at $30 for a fifth from a single barrel, 11-year-old bourbon is very hard to complain about.
